text: Transcription factor NF-kappa B must be released from cytoplasmic inhibitory molecules ( I kappa Bs ) in order to move to the nucleus and to activate its target genes .
Little is known about the mechanisms regulating the maintenance of constitutive nuclear NF-kappa B in some cell-types and of sustained nuclear NF-kappa B activity after stimulation .
Increased turnover has been implicated in the regulation of constitutive NF-kappa B activity in mature B cells .

We therefore compared the turnover of <extra_id_0> I kappa B alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> I kappa B beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in mature B cells and HeLa cells .

Both proteins display a high turnover in B cells although <extra_id_0> I kappa B beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is considerably more stable than <extra_id_0> I kappa B alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
The half-life of both inhibitors is increased in HeLa cells .
In contrast , all other NF-kappa B / I kappa B molecules tested are relatively stable in both cell-types .

The elevated turnover of endogenous <extra_id_0> I kappa B alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in Namalwa cells is inhibited by a proteasome inhibitor and thus seems to be driven by the same degradation machinery as the slower turnover in non-B cells .

Furthermore , we investigated the processes involved in persistent activation of NF-kappa B . <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling leads to a rapid depletion of cellular <extra_id_0> I kappa B beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> pools .

text: NF-kappa B binding activity can be detected for several hours after stimulation .
We found that removal of the <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> containing medium causes a rapid decrease in nuclear NF-kappa B .

A phosphoform of newly synthesized <extra_id_0> I kappa B alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is visible when degradation by the proteasome is inhibited and new <extra_id_0> I kappa B alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> displays the same properties regarding phosphorylation and degradation in response to a second inducer .

text: There is no significant difference in the turnover of pre - and post-inductive <extra_id_0> I kappa B alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

These observations suggest that resynthesis of <extra_id_0> I kappa B alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and removal of the stimulus are obligatory steps for the inactivation of nuclear NF kappa B .
